awd_titl_txt: ADVANCE Partnership: Building Relationships to Increase Diversity and Gender Equity in Hawaii's Two Year College System
awd_abstract_narration:
The project, which is a partnership between the University of Hawaii Community College (UHCC) system and the University of Hawaii Hilo (UHH), will identify and address unique obstacles to the retention and career progress of STEM women faculty of different race and ethnic groups in the context of seven remote community college campuses. The project will use virtual tools to connect these remote campus locations in mentoring and coaching trainings for administrators and senior faculty, and will implement a mentoring and coaching program for women STEM faculty of diverse race/ethnic backgrounds. This project will provide a model for addressing the challenges STEM women faculty face in two-year colleges and in remote locations. 

The project will generate systemic change for gender equity in the context of community colleges through a multi-stage process involving: institution-specific assessments of barriers to equity; implementation of proven strategies for change developed at the University of Hawaii Hilo and other previous ADVANCE institutions; and coaching and mentoring programs involving over 400 men and women in STEM fields on the seven University of Hawaii Community College campuses. These strategies will involve the use and evaluation of virtual tools for multi-institutional participation across remote island locations, and the training of up to 60 mentors (senior STEM men and women faculty) and 32 coaches (STEM women faculty), who will in turn serve a minimum of 75-100 unique participants, and be sustainable and scalable to other fields and to other UHCC system and University of Hawaii campuses. Coaching and mentoring programs are designed with the unique circumstances of smaller institutions in mind and will be further informed by the institutional assessments. The approach implemented with this project will be disseminated as a model for other 2-year college campuses and campus systems nationally. 

The NSF ADVANCE program is designed to foster gender equity through a focus on the identification and elimination of organizational barriers that impede the full participation and advancement of women faculty in academic institutions.  Organizational barriers that inhibit equity may exist in policies, processes, practices, and the organizational culture and climate.

por.por_cntn:
Building Relationships to Increase Diversity and Gender Equity (BRIDGE) was funded by the NSF ADVANCE program in 2017 with an award of $1,099,959. NSF ADVANCE is dedicated to improving the academic employment conditions of women in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM). Our research and programming has focused primarily on women faculty at the seven community colleges within the University of Hawai’i (UH) System and their diverse experiences from an intersectional perspective. In 2021 we received a supplemental grant of $150,324 so we may include the two four year higher education in the UH System in our data collection and the mentorship and coaching program we created for advancing women faculty and supporting their diverse experiences based on race, indigeneity, ethnicity, and class among other factors such as being a parent. 

Our research consisted of both qualitative and quantitative data collection on nine campuses. In terms of the qualitative data collection we conducted 76 in-depth audio-recorded interview with faculty. Since we were seeking to understand how employment conditions across UH campuses varied by race, ethnicity, and indigeneity we sought interviews with faculty members across race, ethnic, and indigenous categories as defined by the State of Hawai’i and the US Census Bureau. Fifty-five percent of our interviews participants identified as Asian, Pacific Islander, Native Hawaiian, Latina/o/x, Black, or other. Our analytical approach was grounded theory. Our qualitative analysis revealed that some faculty struggle to meet the cost of living in Hawaiʻi despite working full time as college faculty; parent faculty, particularly women, struggle to meet childcare needs; and that race and ethnicity and immigrant status shape work experiences. We also found that faculty have heard of or experienced biases based on their gender, race, ethnicity, and indigeneity and that bullying occurs across campuses, though at some more than others. One of the most exciting findings is that many Native Hawaiian, Pacific Islander, and Asian women developed their own systems of support when campuses did not offer it in terms of career opportunities and childcare.

The statistical analysis of our quantitative data which consists of 773 complete surveys by faculty from the nine campuses included in our study affirms our qualitative findings. Our analysis was able to demonstrate the higher number of hours women dedicate to service and teaching which is consistent with the academic literature on gender, employment, and higher education. We also found that women faculty often did not feel supported by upper administration, and were not well informed or directed in preparing for tenure and promotion. Our final report which includes these analyses (both qualitative and quantitative) was made available on our website advancehawaii.org and was shared with participants and administrators. We also presented our findings and recommendations at UH and in academic conferences over the five years of the grant.

The second objective of our ADVANCE Partnerships grant was to implement a mentorship and coaching training program. Mentorship is when a faculty with more experience with the processes and the opportunities on a campus, in higher education, or a field, supports those with less experience. Coaching occurs by creating a network of faculty with a range of experiences that support each other as a collective. Our mentorship and coaching networks involved faculty from across campuses. We trained three cohorts of coaches and mentors. Our training program shifted due to Covid-19 and being unable to meet in person. We created three on-line modules on Laulima, UH’s learning management system and with Sutori, an interactive teaching tool. Along with on-line content, we coordinated three hours Zoom training sessions per each module with experts in mentorship and coaching, community colleges, and gender and diversity in higher education. We held a follow up discussion group one week after each training session. 

Our training modules for mentoring and coaching were informed by the data we collected. We emphasized a place-based approach. Our first module drew on the frameworks of leadership and community building in Native Hawaiian knowledge systems. Our second module presents intersectionality and how it applies to mentorship and coaching and strategies for intervening when gender or race, ethnic, and indigenous bias is occurring. Our second module also included experts on the distinct kind of biases and discrimination that occur to some groups in Hawai’i. Our final module focused on navigating the UH system when one needs to get help, address, or respond to discrimination and bias.

We trained 73 faculty, almost evenly split between coaching and mentoring. An additional 50 faculty were mentored by a faculty trained in mentorship by BRIDGE. In addition, a trained faculty per each of the nine campuses has taken on the role of campus leader for growing BRIDGE on their campus and working across campuses with other campus leaders. We have also contacted campus administrators requesting funding and to institutionalize our efforts.
